channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Protesters Urge Guggenheim to Aid Abu Dhabi Workers
item.description: About 40 protesters critical of the Guggenheim Museum’s planned franchise in Abu Dhabi smuggled their own artworks into the museum on Saturday evening.
item.dc:creator: By COLIN MOYNIHAN

item.title: For Crimea, It’s Russian Troops in, Tourists Out
item.description: With its economy flatlining, Crimea desperately needs a banner year in tourism. But with the violent portrait Russian television has painted of Ukraine, few seem likely to come.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A public beach in Yalta, the Black Sea resort city in southern Crimea that is facing a tough summer if vacationers stay away.

item.title: Pope Calls for Solutions to Conflicts in Mideast Visit
item.description: At the start of a three-day trip through the Holy Land, Pope Francis called for a “peaceful” solution to the war in Syria and a “just” solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Pope Francis waved to the crowd on Saturday following a mass in Amman.

item.title: Egypt’s New Autocrat, Sisi Knows Best
item.description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s cunning path to power and his paternalistic conviction that the people must be prepared to suffer are illuminated in interviews and leaked recordings.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A banner for the soon-to-be-elected president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, displayed in Cairo in March.

item.title: Turkish Film ‘Winter Sleep’ Wins Top Honor at Cannes
item.description: Directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan, the film explores life and death, good and evil, the beauty of the natural world and the art of conversation.
item.dc:creator: By MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: In Possible Thaw, Pakistani Leader Agrees to Attend Swearing-In Ceremony in India
item.description: The invitation by Narendra Modi, India’s new prime minister, indicated a possible upturn in relations between the two longtime rivals.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi, arriving at the parliament building in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: Militants Attack Somalia’s Parliament
item.description: Witnesses and officials reported a bomber detonating a car filled with explosives at the Parliament building’s entrance, followed by several explosions and an assault by gunmen.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: A Somali soldier ran toward Parliament as others took cover in Mogadishu on Saturday.

item.title: 3 Shot Dead at Brussels Jewish Museum
item.description: An unidentified gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum in central Brussels, killing at least three people.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Observers Go to Ukraine for Election Separatists Plan to Disrupt
item.description: An official from the unrecognized Donetsk People’s Republic said that his group had confiscated official voting center stamps and some ballots.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Obama to Detail a Broader Foreign Policy Agenda
item.description: The president is expected to chart in a speech at West Point a middle course between isolationism and military intervention in international conflicts, from Syria’s civil war to Russia’s incursions in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama, with Chancellor Angela Merkel on Friday, will reveal specifics of his foreign policy agenda on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinn Fein Benefits as Ireland Moves Left
item.description: Early election results showed the government coalition parties, Fine Gael and Labour, had each lost significant levels of support.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Lebanon’s Political Standoff Leaves Leadership Vacancy
item.description: Reaching agreements among the country’s myriad political parties and religious sects has become more difficult in recent years, as the country’s politicians have lined up on opposite sides of the civil war in neighboring Syria.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Junta Targets Scholars for New Detentions as Thai Forces Are Sent to Protests
item.description: Members of the junta sought to consolidate their power, “terminating” the upper house of Parliament and summoned professors and writers to give them “time to think.”
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators clashed with Thai forces in Bangkok on Saturday as they protested Thursday’s military coup.

item.title: Iran Billionaire Hanged for Fraud
item.description: Mahafarid Amir Khosravi had been convicted of playing a major role in a $2.6 billion corruption case, the biggest in Iran since the 1979 revolution.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why D.S.K. Won’t Go Away
item.description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s comeback says a lot about the state of French politics.
item.dc:creator: By Sylvie Kauffmann

item.title: Election of President Seen as a Beginning to Repairing Ukraine
item.description: For some, the election Sunday to replace the ousted president represents the culmination of six months of protests, but for others, there is nothing to celebrate — yet.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Ukrainian election officials on Saturday prepared a voting station at a school in Kiev for Sunday’s presidential election.

item.title: Citing Fraud, Malawi Leader Halts Vote and Stirs Protest
item.description: President Joyce Banda on Saturday canceled Malawi’s elections, citing fraud and “rampant irregularities.”
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: News Analysis: Deterrence Revisited
item.description: Do our adversaries feel free to ignore the rules of global order?
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: A Russia supporter at a rally in Simferopol, Crimea, in February.

item.title: Soldiers and Militants Clash in Yemen City
item.description: Fifteen militants and at least 10 soldiers are reported killed in an attack on army, security and government buildings in the southern city Sayoun.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China’s Leader, Seeking to Build Its Muscle, Pushes Overhaul of the Military
item.description: President Xi Jinping wants a military that can project power across the Pacific and face regional rivals like Japan.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: China’s military budget is the second largest in the world, behind that of the United States.

item.title: Suspects in China Market Attack Identified
item.description: Four of the men were killed when the two vehicles they used to mount the attack exploded in Urumqi, the regional capital.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Tempting Europe With Ugly Fruit
item.description: Isabel Soares has bet that there is a market for fruits and vegetables deemed too ugly by government bureaucrats, supermarkets and other retailers to sell to their consumers.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A volunteer with Fruta Feia, or Ugly Fruit, with a strawberry deemed too deformed by European officials to sell in ordinary food outlets.

item.title: When Cannabis Goes Corporate
item.description: With a sweeping new policy for medical marijuana, Canada is aiming for a market of large-scale — and highly regulated — growers.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marijuana plants grow under artificial sunlight in one of the many climate-controlled rooms at Tweed Marijuana in Smiths Falls, Ontario. Tweed is one of about 20 companies that are licensed to grow medical marijuana in Canada.

item.title: World Briefing: Separatist Rebels in Mali Agree to a Truce
item.description: Tuareg separatist groups in Mali on Friday accepted a cease-fire agreement with the government after clashes this week that threatened to plunged the country back into war.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: 6 Gunned Down on Bus in El Salvador
item.description: Gunmen boarded a bus in a town near San Salvador, the Salvadoran capital, opened fired on passengers, killing six, including three law enforcement officials, the police said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
